section.title: Introduction to HTML
section.content: On a typical webpage, there are three distinct software technologies that define how the webpage looks, feels, and functions. These are known as HTML, CSS, and JS.
HTML is a Markup Language that defines the structure of a webpage. CSS and JS (which will be covered in Unit 2) define how a page looks and functions.
In this first unit, we will explore some common HTML tags.

section.title: Basic Tags
section.subtitle: The Div:
section.content: The div is the most basic tag. It is commonly used to help structure a page. It has no special preformatting.
section.subtitle: The Paragraph:
section.content: The paragraph tag is commonly used to display text on a webpage since it uses preformatting. Browsers will add a blank line after a p tag.
section.subtitle: The Head, Body and Html Tags <html></html> <body></body> <head></head>
section.content: These elements are used to define the page. Browsers will only process pages that contain a properly formatted HTML tag. All content goes inside this tag.
Head tags contain metadata about the page, as well as links to both external and internal sources (such as JS scripts and CSS stylesheets).
The body tag contains the actual HTML that will display in the browser window.

section.title: Forms
section.content: Forms are the primary way of entering information into a webpage. A form element is used to define the form itself, and a number of different inputs can be used to aquire information from the user.
section.subtitle: Input Tags
section.content: Input tags are basic elements which can accept many different forms of data from a user, wether that be words, numbers, dates etc. These are often used in applications such as login forms.
